div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1906.
THE ELECTION.
div.p: The extraordinary defeat of the ex-Prime Minister at Manchester and the recent great Liberal gains look as though the polling is going strong against the Unionists. But it must be remembered that the Liberal- Labour party has a great many victories yet to win, for in order to gain a majority of fifty over Unionists and Nationalists, the party must perform the almost superhuman feat of capturing no fewer than 172 seats, counting 341 votes on a division. This, extravagant as it appears, is actually forty votes lower than the forecast of Mr. W. T. Stead, who predicted a turnover of 192 seats, counting 384 on a division. We now trace the fl act nation in the voting since the General Election of 1895 :
In 1895 Unionist polling was 12 percent higher than Anti Unionist.
In 1895-1909 Unionist polling was 3-1/2 percent. lower than Anti-Unionist.
In 1900 Unionist polling was 12 percent. higher than Anti-Unionist.

In 1903-1905 Unionist polling was 12 percent lower than Anti-Unionist From this table it is dear that if by-polling were a direct index to General Election polling —and this is the assumption upon which the hopes of a Liberal-Labour majority have admittedly been founded—the Unionist Government would have been beaten in 1900 by a 3-1/2 percent majority of the electorate. As it was, the 3-1/2 percent, minority was converted into a 12 percent majority—a turnover of 15-1/2 percent, in all. This 15-1/2 percent, in fact, is the figure of discount to be allowed for anti- Ministerial bias. If events follow in 1906 the fairly regular course they have taken since 1895—and there is nothing to show that they will not do so—the 12 per cent by election Unionist minority will be converted into a 8-1/2 percent. General Election Unionist majority. This would give the Unionist party a small majority of perhaps thirty seats in Great Britain only. Assuming that Ireland returns eighty-two Nationalist and twenty-one Unionist members, the Unionist party would be left in a minority in the House of Commons of thirty- one—the Government majority being composed of Liberal, Labour, and Nationalist members.

This calculation opens the way to a number of possibilities, all of uncommon interest. In the first place, the majority of (approximately) thirty-one is the highest majority which Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman can hope for, as attested by Liberal statistics — unless the course of political feeling in the country is to be completely diverted from its accustomed channel. If the Prime Minister can perform -this feat, he may obtain a majority of perhaps sixty members. Will he do so 1 In the light of the events of the last few days there is no warrant for supposing that it is impossible.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Deutsche Orient Bank. The Alexandria branch of the Deutsche Orient Bank baa been at work since the 3rd inst., and the branch at Cairo will be established shortly. Fire at Alexandria. Fire broke out yesterday in a furniture shop belonging to Mursi Ambar, in the Souk El Kanto, and was extinguished by the Fire- Brigade. The damage has not yet been estimated. French Chamber of Commerce. The December number of the Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce of Alexandria contains an analysis of the Financial Adviser’s Note, and a mass of useful information on Egypt’s financial and commercial progress. Egyptian Enterprise Co. On the 15th October M. Toussaint Canere sold to the Egyptian Enterprise and Development Co. for £350,00 a quantity of land at Boulac. On Friday last this identical piece of land was resold by the company for £04.500. The Municipal Elections. It will not be inopportune to remind those of our readers who are not on the lists of voters for the Alexandria Municipal elections, that they have only up to the 1st inst. to apply, after that date no application for the municipal franchise can be entertained. In a Few Months. To obtain in a short time a result which formerly often required long months of study, such is the advantage the Berlitz School offers, which explains its universal success. Berlitz School of Languages : Alexandria, 26, Rue de l’Eglise Copte; Cairo 1, BhariaKameL [Advt.] The Kahil Property. It is announce! that Mme Veuve Kahil Pacha refuses to sell her property and garden in the Ismailia quarter of Cairo for L.E. 105,0o0. Some companies have offered even up to L.E. 170,000 in annual payments for this property, but these offers have not been entertained. Mother and Daughter Asphyxiated. On a cold night, a few days ago, a native woman and her daughter, of Kafr Sakr, went to bed in a dosed room with a charcoal fire. In the morning the mother and daughter we found dead in their beds. The post-mortem examination showed that death was due to suffocation. Alexandria’s Tranquility. The celebration of Greek New Year’s Day passed off very quietly. Every precaution had been taken by the Alexandria City Police to cope with any disturbance that might occur. The guards at each police station throughout the city were doubled and mounted policemen patrolled the streets, but there was not the slightest disturbance. In fact, the tranquility of the city now-a-days is absolutely unparalleled. Death of Mr. Stiliano Platidis, We regret to announce the death of the director of the Greek Hospital at Alexandria, Mr. Stiliano Platidis, which occurred early on Saturday morning from heart disease. The funeral took place on Saturday afternoon, at 4.30 o’clock, and was largely attended by all classes of the Hellenic community of Alexandria, by whom the deceased was held in high esteem. The Kaiser’s Birthday. On the occasion of the forty-seventh anniversary of the birthday of the Kaiser, a grand fete will be given by the German colony at Cairo at 3:30 p.m. at the German school. On the following day, there will be a thanksgiving service at 10 a.m. in the German Church in the Ismailia quarter, at 11 a.m. a reception at the German Agency, at 7.30 p.m. a banquet at the German Club.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: ELECTION CAMPAIGN.
MR. BLAFOUR DEFEATED.
TIDE FLOWING WITH LIBERALS.
London, January 13. The Liberals Messrs. D. F. Goddard and F. T. Cobbold have been elected for Ipswich. The election of the latter constitutes a Liberal gain. (Reuter)

London, January 13. The following Members have been returned unopposed: RiahtHon. James W. Lowther (C.), Penrith. Sir J. Kitson,Bait.(L), Colne. Mr. 8. T Evans L.), Mid Glamorgan. Mr. J. G, Talbot (UA and Sir W. Anson (U), Oxford University. Messrs. Carion (U.) and J. H. M. Campbell (U.), Dublin University. Messrs. 0 Bnen and Roohe(Nationalists), Cork.Messe W.Field (N) And Mannetti (N.), Dublin.Hon.F.W. Lambtou (U.), Durham. _ . . Hitherto 38 Liberals and 12 Unionists have been eleoted. Liberal gains 16. Later. 45 Liberals and 12 Unionists have been returned liberal gains 22. Manchester. E. Mr. Harridge (L.), 6403. Mr. Balfour (C.), 4323. (Reuter)

London, January 13. It is believed that a safe seat has been found for Mr. Balfour at Eccles. Unionist clubs recognize the fact that the tide is Bowing with the Liberals, and are preparing for the worst. Even strong candidates are beginning to quake, knowing that vacillators always follow the lead of previous elections. Liberal headquarters are proportionately jubilant and are confident of a big independent majority (Reuter)

div.head: MOROCCO CONFERENCE
div.p: COUNT TATTENBACH HOPEFUL.

Paris, January 13. Count Tattenbach, German delegate at the Morocco Conference, has passed through Paris on his way to Algesiras. In an interview he expressed the hope that the Conference would have good results. (Havas)
Paris, January 14. Interviewed here, Count Tattenbach said that he expected that the Morocco Conference will last two months. He was convinced that an agreement will be reached. (Reuter)
Algesiras, January 14. The Morocco delegates have arrived. (H)

div.head: FRANCE AND VENEZUELA.
div.p: DIPLOMATIC RUPTURE.
Paris, January 13. Diplomatic relations with Venezuela have been broken off. (Reuter)
New York, January 12. Telegraphic communications with Venezuela are interrupted. (Reuter)

div.head: BANK OF FRANCE NOTES.
div.p: INCREASE OF CIRCULATION.

Paris, January 13. The circulation' of Bank of France notes having reached the maximum, the Government has introduced a bill increasing the circulation by 800,000,000 francs in order to avert the depletion of the metal reserve. (R.)

div.head: STATE OF RUSSIA.
div.p: MASSACRES IN THE CAUCASUS.
St. Petersburg, January 13. Tartars and Armenians in Caucasia continue to burn each other’s villages, massacring the inhabitants and attacking the troops. (Reuter)
Tiflis, January 13. Normal circulation has been re-established on the Trans Caucasian Railways. (Havas)

div.head: NEW ORLEANS COTTON GROWERS.
div.p: FAVOUR HOLDING COTTON.
The New Orleans Convention of Cotton Growers has passed a resolution in favor of holding cotton until a price of 15 cents per pound be reached. (Reuter)

div.head: REPUBLICANS' DUTY
div.p: Paris, January 14. In a speech delivered at the Jardiea, M. Etienne extolled the teachings of Gambetta, which would forever point out to France thé Republican patriotic duty. (Havas)

div.head: C.M.G. FOR MACAULEY BEY.
div.p: London, January 13. Major Macauley has been created Companion of Saint Michael and Saint George on account of services in connection with the Suakin-Berber Railway. (Reuter)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL.
div.p: London, January 13. Football. Rugby. Wales beat England by 16 to 3. (Reuter)

div.head: REPORTED FUSION OF HAMBURG-AMERIKA AND N.D.L.S.CO
div.p: A report is current in Berlin financial circles which ought to be well informed that further negotiations between the Hamburg- Amerika and North German Lloyd Steamship Companies have brought a fusion of the two undertakings considerably nearer realization. Although the dispute was settled a fortnight ago, further conferences between Herr Ballin and Herr Wiegand took place towards the end of last week, and it is said that the question of amalgamation was discussed in detail.

It is further stated that these two gentlemen drew np the outlines of a definite schema for presentation to the general meeting of their respective companies. It is impossible to obtain definite particulars of what has passed, owing to the fact that both companies persistently refuse all information. It is certain, however, that one or two of the leading financial houses in Berlin have made extensive purchases of the shares of both the Hamburg and the Bremen companies in anticipation of amalgamation, which would probably result in considerable financial gain to the shareholders of both.

It is also stated the contracts which the North German Lloyd recently concluded with the Russian Government for the transport of troops from Vladivostok to Odessa contained a clause providing for the possibility of fusion.

TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft; Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez, tor twelve months from 1st April 1906.
Each article should be tendered for separately, bat the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm must be placid on the same form.

Prices should be quoted in English currency. Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate, Port Said, to whom tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1906.

div.head: NEW EGYPT
div.p: INTERESTING EXTRACTS

A few days ago we reviewed M. A. de Guerrilla's recently published work "New Egypt." This lively book lends itself to some extracts, which will give our readers some idea of the excellence of its contents. Here is a description of some aspects of Cairo in the season, which in some persons' opinion may justify the appellation of "Grave of the Soul" which has been bestowed on the gay capital of Egypt There is something in the air of Egypt, a something which seems to excite every one, more or less, which almost maddens certain natures, especially of the weaker sex, and which seems to drive them to a continuous pursuit of all the pleasures of the senses. The result is that all the world flirts, and the most extraordinary stories ran the round of the hotels. Young girls seem to have a very pronounced weakness for the Egyptian, a weakness which sometimes seems to lead to an entire absence of any idea of “les convenances.” A young Egyptian glib of tongue and an excellent dancer once said to me : "I assure you I could write a volume of adventures which come the way of us young Egyptians in winter, and the way in which these young girls throw themselves at our. beads would astonish the world. Several of us, for sport, formed a society which we called the 'terras siers,’ because we ‘did’ the terraces of the various hotels, but it was no use, we had to give it up ; no constitution could stand the success which covered our efforts." But the adventures of these young blades pale before those of the dragomans, these splendid men, built like Hercules, strong as horses, and so picturesque in their native costume. Their duty is to serve as guide and interpreter, to organize everything for their masters, excursions and parties of all sorts. Like the Arabs, the Egyptians and all the Orientals from the lowest to the highest, the dragomans are mad where a European or an American woman is concerned. For them they represent the acme of sexual attraction, and at least, for the lowest class, age and looks are quite unimportant. One can then perhaps understand, if not forgive, the woman whose looks have suffered from the passing of the years, or who, born with a lack of the fatal gift, bas lingered long in the cold shades of neglect, seizing eagerly the opportunity of becoming an object or adoration, in engaging an Egyptian dragoman. Than follow some curious stories. The tale of the young American girl and the "moustiquaire" is in fact far too risqué for our chaste columns.
The Cairo Season.

Elsewhere the author remarks :— "In this continual round of fetes and pleasures of dinners, balls, and suppers, all the world of Cairo and his wife amuse themselves and flirt as to this flirtation, I am convinced that in no other city in the world does it play so large a part; and yet it, seems, I was not there at the proper time. I left too soon. Winter, it seems, is nothing coppered with spring, when, as we know, a young man’s fancy lightly turns.... “I am leaving Cairo,” a friend of mine wrote me in April, a lady whom one could not describe as a prude, "I am leaving Cairo, for I can not stand any longer the sight of these couples, who, now that the hot weather has come, seem to have lost all notion of les convenances." Well, chère amie, we must not be too hard on poor Cairo. Spring is the great sinner in all lands; and if he seems somewhat more alive there than elsewhere, is it his fault, is it not rather the fault of the climate and sun
Society In Cairo.

Apropos of the wealthy European and Levantine Society in Cairo, our author says:- The origin of many of their fortunes, though not unknown or even forgotten, is wisely bidden by a thick veil, which old residents occasionally amuse themselves by lifting for the entertainment of curious persons like myself. Then it is that they tickle your ears with stories of which the heroes, bearers of names well known and respected, proud of their titles and decorations, strong in their relationships and friends, appear in the early stages of their careers as nothing more or less than robbers, smugglers, and coiners. But after all, what does it matter? The elders, those who have struggled and suc- ceded at a time when every one robbed more or lets, are to-day very old. Tomorrow they will have gone, and another generation, well brought op, highly educated, elegant, fashionable to the tips of their fingers, will not be responsible for the kind of money which their fathers used. Do not let us dig too deep. Out of a dunghill a rose may grow and many another beautiful thing. And besides, as every one knows, money has no smell, and less even in Egypt than elsewhere.
The Alexandrian

Here is his description of the typical Alexandrian:— For several years the mania for speculation seems to have attacked the whole population, and the stock exchange at Alexandria is, as it were, the heart of the body politic, full of life, of hopes and fears,where every one, large and small, rich or poor, strong or weak, meets on common ground. Cotton, its rise or fall, that is the predominant thought in the minds of all those men amongst whom are so many familiar faces. Indeed, after nine months' scraping and hoarding, these good Alexandrians troop across to Paris and the best known watering-places on the continent, to disgorge in the remaining three months their accumulated gains. All have the look of men well pleased with the world, and all explain themselves thus, "My dear fellow, business is A.I Egypt has entered on an era of prosperity hardly credible. We are making money hand over fist, every one is in the swim. You will see for yourself, from one end of Egypt to the other you will hear the same story. The Government has been able to reduce taxation and increase the salaries of its employees, big and little. The golden age has arrived !" Can this be possible can it be that, whilst in Europe and America every one cries poverty, there is only prosperity here in this land of Egypt, which scarcely twenty years ago was in a state of bankruptcy and, strange as it may seem, not one of these men will speak to you of Egypt, of its history, of its artistic treasures, not one of them will advise you to visit a museum, a monument or a park. The Stock Exchange and cotton, these are the be-all and end-all of existence. If by chance they do advise you to go the theatre, it will not be because there is something particularly good to be seen, but simply because ‘ X receives £1,000 for three performances, and that the stones and jewels in the hair or round the necks of the elegant represent a sum of £10,000,000 sterling !" When he talks cotton or diamonds, your Alexandrian is a bit of a braggart. In a word, his head is a money-box, and his heart a purse, and they are loth crammed to repletion with banknotes. All the same he is a good fellow, pleasant, hospitable and generous. If he has the faults of the confirmed gambler he has also his good qualities. As to his better-half, it is difficult to judge. Admiration has perhaps blinded me, for the ‘'Alexandrine" is so pretty, so elegant, and so chic, that criticism is quite disarmed. One would have to travel far to find a town where there are so many young women whore good looks and perfect elegance continually charm the eye. It may be said, of course, that they are shallow, that their dresses, their jewels, and especially their flirtations are of more interest to them than the graver questions of life; but what does that matter when they are so charming, and so deliciously feminine? Certainly, we are far from the time when in Alexandria there was a famine of femininity either d'un monde ou de l'aotre.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
R. INNISKILLING FUSILIERS REGIMENTAL SHIELD (FIRST ROUND).
F. Company v. G. Company.

The above well-known rivals met on Thursday evening at Kaar-el-Nil barracks to decide who should enter the second round of the above competition. Both teams hold a good reputation. It will be remembered F. Company secured a runners-up position in the football tournament They possess the proud record of having beaten the regimental team at one time in India. Both elevens have been going "great guns” and were determined to win. The ground was in the pink of condition and a hot sixty minutes was in store for those who lined the ropes at the appointed time for starting. The ground was well packed. There were about 1,600 spectators present when the referee's whistle announced time for hostilities to commence. Appended are the teams : F. Company—goal, Collins ; backs, Duffy and Page; halves, Harbinson, Walker, and Smyth ; forwards, Perey, Bradshaw, Collins, Tracey. and Boy Armstrong. G. Company—Goal, McCaffery; backs,Millarand Bothwell; halves, Dugan, Lyons, and Patterson; forwards, Dutton, Garret, Higginson, Mitchel, and Greer.
THE GAME.

F. Company started minus Templeton, who was on the side list, Tracey filling the vacancy. Collins started the ball a-rolling and play was at once taken towards McCaffery, but Both well cleared at a critical moment. Not to be denied the Greens still pressed but the ball found touch four times in succession. A near goal ended in a corner which proved unproductive. G Company now found their feet, Greer making good headway, but Duffy came to the rescue and play was in a trice transferred towards McCaffery when Percy had hard lines, his final shot missing the post by a hair's-breadth. On the kick-off Lyons got possession and gave to Dutton, but the latter dallied on the ball too long and a chance was lost Midfield play now followed and a free kick relieved matters. This let G Company away, Higginson showing fine form and giving his wing men some splendid opportunities, but Duffy and Company were in splendid form and repelled all attacks. At this stage the excitement was intense, each team doing their utmost. F Company now took play in hand and Walker was seen to advantage The new recruit slipped in a daisy cutter and McCaffery just managed to save the ball finding touch. Play became faster and Walker in attempting to score struck the crossbar which shook the ball, rebounding on to the toe of one of the Greens, who sent in a fast shot, McCaffery saving weakly, with the result that Percy walked the ball clean into the net for the Greenshirts after twenty minutes’ play, amid tremendous cheers. On resuming, G Company got away in fine style but Page outwitted Garret and sent strongly up the field, where Tracey got the ball, but Patterson robbed and play was transferred, when Collins came in for a lively time He however saved marvelously but had to acknowledge defeat at the hands of Higginson. Amidst deafening cheers midfield play now followed, but nothing of importance occurred up to half-time the score standing : F. Company, 1 goal, G Company, 1 goal.
SECOND HALF

The second moiety was resumed and the green shirts got going in fine style until a free kick against Tracey spoilt a golden opportunity. Play however remained in midfield, where Collins appealed to the referee for being fouled twice in succession, but no notice was taken. Garret and Dutton were combining well and the latter centered well. Mitchell receiving sent strongly in to Collins, who saved in a brilliant manner. Still the stripes hovered around Collins, but all to no purpose as that custodian was in fine form. Good play by Smyth resulted in Armstrong getting on a single-handed run, but his shot went behind. Neither team could claim any advantage, each goal being visited in turn, and the backs on each side being very stubborn. Tracey now got a good chance to add to the score, but he fell in attempting to shoot Both sets of forwards were showing good form. F Company now got down per Peroy, who sent well in, but Millar relieved, the ball finding touch. The referee’s ruling of the game seemed most unfair to both teams. The game was rough for a while and G Company's goal bad a very narrow escape, splendid play by Millar averting disaster. The pace was now very fast, and each goal was visited without result Duffy received a great cheer for taking the ball from the toe of Dugan and punting well down the field, where some exciting play took place around McCaffery, who saved at the expense of a corner. This was wall taken by Armstrong, but Lyons relieved and G Company were seen to advantage, Greer getting away on a good run, but be sent behind. On resuming Collins and Bradshaw combining well got close to McCaffery, but Bothwell robbed Collins when in the act of shooting, the ball finding touch. From the throw in Armstrong got on a singlehanded run and dodging a couple of opponents sent in a low, swift shot which struck the side of the post and rebounded into the net but to the dissatisfied supporters of F Company the referee disallowed the goal and gave a corner. Tbiss was cleared by Millar and G Company's forwards got a-going, but Page robbed in the nick of time. Play from this to the end was very exciting, but neither team could add to their score, and the long whistle sounded shortly after for full time, leaving the game a draw and to be replayed at a future date :— F Company .... 1 goal G Company .... 1 goal.

div.head: FOOTBALL AT PORT SAID
div.p: (From Our Correspondent)

Port Said, Friday. This afternoon the Port 8aid Football Club played a return match with a team from the H. M. S Diana, now stationed at Port Said. From the start the Diana forwards showed their superiority over our forwards in passing and quickness and found our weakest spot, namely, our halves. In the first half the "boys in blue" had most of the attacking to do, and it was only the wonderful play of Williams at toll back which kept the ball from the net However, just before half time the Diana scored a goal, which was well deserved, after some very good play. Soon after the restart half time was scored. Up to now the home halves had been giving a very poor account of themselves and everybody was disappointed in the forwards, with the exception of Gunnery, who was playing a really splendid game. Id the second half things were a little more even, but still the Diana had the best of the game and more than once just missed the goal From a corner for the Diana, Gunnery got away, and passed man after man on his own, and after running the length of the field scored a goal with a wonderfully good shot This was without doubt the run of the game and Mr. Gunnery is to be congratulated on his fine run. It is hardly worth while saying anything about the remainder of the game as it consisted mainly of fouls, although the Diana scored another goal, and thereby won the match by 3 to 1.

div.head: ACCIDENT ON GREAT EASTERN RAILWAY (ENGLAND)
div.p: As the outcome of the accident on the Great Eastern Railway (England), on 1st September last, in which it will be remembered ten people were killed and about twenty injured, and in which a carriage lighted by gas took fire immediately after the accident, the Great Eastern Railway Company have decided, we are informed, to equip all their new main line rolling stock in the future with Stone’s System of Electric Lighting instead of gas as heretofore.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt fur too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

They are as follows The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones ore us follows;— Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days Alexandria to Messina 3 „ Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 „ Alexandria to Venice and Trieste... 4 „ Alexandria to Naples 3 „ Port Said to Genoa 5 „ Port Said to Naples 4 „ Alexandria to Constantinople ... 4 „ Alexandria to l’ineus 2 „ Port Said to Gibraltar 7 „

The steamers, of the P. and 0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt. As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours. The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the “Perry boats,” having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at .Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for j sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is thc station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Beale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovanni degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Llovd leave Alexandria every Wednesday 1 during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 8 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment hero. Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers arid its surrounding country. In Florence itself the ! churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks m Europe, opened 85 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that te Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ;here there is a fine Cathedral jand the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should If possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable ; and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most I picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings are a constant delight to thousands of travelers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.

From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the. Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an j hour and-a- half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and THE ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea-port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.

Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza : Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lakeis most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremzzp, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as “A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Basso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment,” by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt.” by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snowclad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Lite of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerns to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn. THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTERLAKEN a favorite summer resort and the best center for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous .waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach and Staubboch. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be “ CHATEAUD’OEX. 3,600 ft. above the sea on the new Elec trio Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
